greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Decimal expansion of sqrt(Pi) / (Gamma(3/4))^2 .
comment: Entry 34 c of chapter 11 of Ramanujan's second notebook.

This constant is also the ratio T(Pi/2)/T(0), where T(Pi/2) is the exact pendulum period for an amplitude of Pi/2 and T(0) the approximate period 2*Pi*sqrt(L/g) for small angles. - _Jean-François Alcover_, Aug 05 2014
link: G. C. Greubel, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..5000
Bruce C. Berndt, Chapter 11 of Ramanujan's second notebook, Bull. Lond. Math. Soc. vol 15 no 4 (1983) 273-320.
Claudio Carvalhaes and Patrick Suppes, Approximations for the period of the simple pendulum based on the arithmetic-geometric mean.
formula: Equals 2*sqrt(2)*K(-1)/Pi, where K is the complete elliptic integral of the first kind, K(-1) being A085565. - _Jean-François Alcover_, Jun 03 2014

Reciprocal of A096427. Equals ( Sum_{n = -inf..inf} exp(-Pi*n^2) )^2, a rapidly converging series. For example, summing from n = -5 to n = 5 gives the constant correct to 49 decimal places. - _Peter Bala_, Mar 06 2019
mathematica: First@ RealDigits[N[Sqrt@ Pi/Gamma[3/4]^2, 120]] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Dec 06 2015 *)
results.author: _R. J. Mathar_, Jul 15 2010
ext: A-number typo for sqrt(Pi) corrected by _R. J. Mathar_, Aug 01 2010
